metadata.title: 8 Things you need know before starting an ML project. | by Prudhvi Vajja | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 8 Things you need know before starting an ML project.
metadata.description: NOTE:- This article is meant to guide you through the thought process (Python Modules) and the right kind of questions that you need to answer for creating an Effective Pipeline. Here is a more…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Here is a more Advanced article with example technologies for creating a production-level Pipeline

all_paragraphs: Try creating a Pipeline for your ml project so that others can benefit from your work.
Why the word Pipeline is Misleading as it implies one-way but let’s see how to think in a circular way for ML Pipelines.

NOTE:- This article is meant to guide you through the thought process (Python Modules) and the right kind of questions that you need to answer for creating an Effective Pipeline. Here is a more Advanced article with example technologies for creating a production-level Pipeline, But I would suggest you skim through this before going there.
To Understand about ML Pipeline in an Interactive way check out The Explorer.

🌀There was a time when I thought ML pipelines are these complex design architectures that can only be done by Software Engineers with high coding and system design skills, But that’s not True at all with the help recent technologies such as Amazon SageMaker, Apache Kafka, Microsoft Azure Etc. Pipelines can be automated and maintained in a easy and cost effective way.🌀

Pipelines are a way to organize and automate your code so that not only your future self but others can be able to understand and integrate with it easily. Some of the objectives of an ML Pipeline are:
⦿ Resistant to New Errors.⦿ Real-Time Processing.⦿ Handling efficient Computation and WorkLoad Balance.⦿ Scalable and message driven.
Before you start diving in, building models and predicting the future ask yourself these questions.
What is the Business Problem that you want to solve?
Do you really need a Machine Learning Approach to solve this Problem?
Here are some tips to know if you need a machine learning approach.
Now it’s time to ask domain expects and test your assumptions.
The more questions you ask at this stage the better your model is going to be.
Let’s get on with the boring part and dive into actually predicting the future.

No matter where you or your team collects the data there might be some noise in it. So you should be equipped with tools that can help you clean and integrate the data properly and you should be able to handle all kinds of data types thrown at you.
Although it is not interesting to do it is useful to produce interesting results. Becoz real data doesn’t consist of numerical and categorical features it consists of garbage and others’ Indolence.
Handy Data Cleaning Tools: PrettyPandas, Tabulate, Scrubadub, ftfy, Link for More
Get the status of your data:
Whooo! My data looks stunning and I can’t wait to run my model and get predictions. Not so fast!
This is where the true skills of a data scientist come into the picture.
Take a random sample of your training data (Any size that doesn’t take too much time to run) and you need to dig deep and should be able to answer all your questions such as.
If you do your homework properly you will able to build your model without any worries of the wrong prediction.
How can we answer these questions programmatically? That takes us to our next step 👇

I love visualization, when you draw your data on a chart it reveals unseen patterns, outliers, and things we are not able to see until now. Basic plots such as histograms and scatter plots can tell you a lot about your data
Some of the things that you need to know are:

You don’t want to hurt your model right. If your data contains missing values or outliers are incorrect data types your model will suffer. To run your model smoothly, you need to take the burden of cleaning it.
Now That part you have been waiting so long for. Selecting the model that you want to Run.

It is not easy to choose one model as there is a wide range of models and all the models have their basic assumptions. choosing the model that aligns with your assumptions of the Dataset is also and Artwork done by Data Scientists.

What’s next? Can I run my model now? Yes if you don’t want better results (the risk that you should not be willing to take any matter the cost). This next part is arguably the critical and time-consuming part of the machine learning pipeline. It only comes with experience but I will try to explain as much as I can to help you started. Get ready!
The main idea for feature engineering comes from asking questions and what you have learned from the visualization process above.
Dig Deep — ML Mastery, Medium, Kaggle, Elite, Elite2
WOOOOH……At last! Finally ready for training huh? Sort of:
1.Split Data into Train, Dev, Test:
It’s time to collect your salary. RUN the model.
Libraries: Mxnet, Scikit-Learn, TensorFlow, PyTorch, Cloud AutoML, Pycaret, Theano, Keras, SciPy, NLTK, MLlib, XGBoost, LightGBM, Many More
Sorry! It’s not done Yet. There are some details to evaluate and interpret which makes you stand out from the crowd such as:

There are different metrics to evaluate your model, sometimes you may have to come up with your own metric to evaluate the model performance. Anyways here are some of the common metrics that help you understand what is going wrong in the model or how accurate is the model for the real-world or to understand why is the model even working in the first place. Choosing the right metric
Don’t just run a single model run multiple Regression/Classification models and choose the best one based on the metrics here.
MSE, RMSE, , Adjusted ​ Dig Deep , Interveiw Prespective
Confusion Matrix, Precision, Recall, F1-score, ROC, AUC Dig Deep

Face it you have framed the problem, cleaned the data, did data visualization, selected important features, and did feature engineering. You trained your model again and again by tuning the hyper-parameters and testing on the dev set, what’s left?
Model.Predict(Test_Data) And Deploy (This is an entirely separate topic )
Still there might be a question bugging in your mind.
Everything is fine, but all of this is just theory, how can I implement it?

Ans: As I said earlier Pipelines are just a thought Process to solve a problem in a systematic manner so that it will be easy to debug in the future: There are tools like Amazon SageMaker which takes care of all these steps at high scale and provides with you extra features and tools to organize, monitor, track your models
Check out this Blog (yet to come) where these steps were used to solve a real-world example.
👏 Comment below the links to your best project.👏
In permanent Beta(⚛︎) — Learning, Improving, Evolving. || Decoding stuff by Encoding from scratch.
